speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. A churchyard.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Enter two Clowns, with spades,  and c

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Is she to be buried in Christian burial that

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: wilfully seeks her own salvation?

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: I tell thee she is: and therefore make her grave

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: straight: the crowner hath sat on her, and finds it

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Christian burial.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: own defence?

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Why, 'tis found so.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: It must be 'se offendendo;' it cannot be else. For

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: here lies the point:  if I drown myself wittingly,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: it argues an act: and an act hath three branches: it

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: is, to act, to do, to perform: argal, she drowned

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: herself wittingly.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Nay, but hear you, goodman delver,--

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Give me leave. Here lies the water; good: here

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: stands the man; good; if the man go to this water,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: and drown himself, it is, will he, nill he, he

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: goes,--mark you that; but if the water come to him

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: and drown him, he drowns not himself: argal, he

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: But is this law?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Ay, marry, is't; crowner's quest law.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Will you ha' the truth on't? If this had not been

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out o'

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Christian burial.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Why, there thou say'st: and the more pity that

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: great folk should have countenance in this world to

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: drown or hang themselves, more than their even

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Christian. Come, my spade. There is no ancient

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: gentleman but gardeners, ditchers, and grave-makers:

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: they hold up Adam's profession.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Was he a gentleman?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: He was the first that ever bore arms.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Why, he had none.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Scripture? The Scripture says 'Adam digged:'

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: could he dig without arms? I'll put another

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: question to thee: if thou answerest me not to the

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: purpose, confess thyself--

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Go to.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: What is he that builds stronger than either the

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: mason, the shipwright, or the carpenter?

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: The gallows-maker; for that frame outlives a

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: thousand tenants.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: I like thy wit well, in good faith: the gallows

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: does well; but how does it well? it does well to

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: those that do in: now thou dost ill to say the

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: gallows is built stronger than the church: argal,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: the gallows may do well to thee. To't again, come.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: 'Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: a carpenter?'

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Ay, tell me that, and unyoke.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Marry, now I can tell.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: To't.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Mass, I cannot tell.

speaker: Second Clown
text_entry: Enter HAMLET and HORATIO, at a distance

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dull

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: ass will not mend his pace with beating; and, when

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: you are asked this question next, say 'a

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: grave-maker: 'the houses that he makes last till

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: doomsday. Go, get thee to Yaughan: fetch me a

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: stoup of liquor.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Exit Second Clown

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: He digs and sings

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: In youth, when I did love, did love,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Methought it was very sweet,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: To contract, O, the time, for, ah, my behove,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: O, methought, there was nothing meet.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Has this fellow no feeling of his business, that he

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: sings at grave-making?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Tis e'en so: the hand of little employment hath

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the daintier sense.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: [Sings]

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: But age, with his stealing steps,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Hath claw'd me in his clutch,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: And hath shipped me intil the land,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: As if I had never been such.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Throws up a skull

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That skull had a tongue in it, and could sing once:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: how the knave jowls it to the ground, as if it were

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Cain's jaw-bone, that did the first murder! It

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: might be the pate of a politician, which this ass

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: now o'er-reaches; one that would circumvent God,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: might it not?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: It might, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Or of a courtier; which could say 'Good morrow,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: sweet lord! How dost thou, good lord?' This might

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: be my lord such-a-one, that praised my lord

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: such-a-one's horse, when he meant to beg it; might it not?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why, e'en so: and now my Lady Worm's; chapless, and

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: knocked about the mazzard with a sexton's spade:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: here's fine revolution, an we had the trick to

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: see't. Did these bones cost no more the breeding,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: but to play at loggats with 'em? mine ache to think on't.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: [Sings]

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: A pick-axe, and a spade, a spade,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: For and a shrouding sheet:

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: O, a pit of clay for to be made

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: For such a guest is meet.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Throws up another skull

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: There's another: why may not that be the skull of a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his quillets,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? why does he

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: suffer this rude knave now to knock him about the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: sconce with a dirty shovel, and will not tell him of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: his action of battery? Hum! This fellow might be

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in's time a great buyer of land, with his statutes,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: his recoveries: is this the fine of his fines, and

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: pate full of fine dirt? will his vouchers vouch him

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: no more of his purchases, and double ones too, than

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: very conveyances of his lands will hardly lie in

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: this box; and must the inheritor himself have no more, ha?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Not a jot more, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Is not parchment made of sheepskins?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Ay, my lord, and of calf-skins too.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: in that. I will speak to this fellow. Whose

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: grave's this, sirrah?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Mine, sir.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Sings

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: O, a pit of clay for to be made

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: For such a guest is meet.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I think it be thine, indeed; for thou liest in't.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: You lie out on't, sir, and therefore it is not

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: yours: for my part, I do not lie in't, and yet it is mine.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Thou dost lie in't, to be in't and say it is thine:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'tis for the dead, not for the quick; therefore thou liest.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: 'Tis a quick lie, sir; 'twill away gain, from me to

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: you.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What man dost thou dig it for?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: For no man, sir.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What woman, then?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: For none, neither.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Who is to be buried in't?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: One that was a woman, sir; but, rest her soul, she's dead.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How absolute the knave is! we must speak by the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: card, or equivocation will undo us. By the Lord,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Horatio, these three years I have taken a note of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: it; the age is grown so picked that the toe of the

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier, he

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: gaffs his kibe. How long hast thou been a

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: grave-maker?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Of all the days i' the year, I came to't that day

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: that our last king Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How long is that since?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Cannot you tell that? every fool can tell that: it

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: was the very day that young Hamlet was born; he that

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: is mad, and sent into England.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Why, because he was mad: he shall recover his wits

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: there; or, if he do not, it's no great matter there.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: 'Twill, a not be seen in him there; there the men

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: are as mad as he.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How came he mad?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Very strangely, they say.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How strangely?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Faith, e'en with losing his wits.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Upon what ground?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Why, here in Denmark: I have been sexton here, man

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: and boy, thirty years.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: How long will a man lie i' the earth ere he rot?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: I' faith, if he be not rotten before he die--as we

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: have many pocky corses now-a-days, that will scarce

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: hold the laying in--he will last you some eight year

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: or nine year: a tanner will last you nine year.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why he more than another?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Why, sir, his hide is so tanned with his trade, that

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: he will keep out water a great while; and your water

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: Here's a skull now; this skull has lain in the earth

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: three and twenty years.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Whose was it?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: A whoreson mad fellow's it was: whose do you think it was?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Nay, I know not.

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! a' poured a

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: flagon of Rhenish on my head once. This same skull,

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: sir, was Yorick's skull, the king's jester.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: This?

speaker: First Clown
text_entry: E'en that.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let me see.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Takes the skull

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio: a fellow

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy: he hath

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: borne me on his back a thousand times; and now, how

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: abhorred in my imagination it is! my gorge rims at

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: it. Here hung those lips that I have kissed I know

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: not how oft. Where be your gibes now? your

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: gambols? your songs? your flashes of merriment,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: that were wont to set the table on a roar? Not one

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: now, to mock your own grinning? quite chap-fallen?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Now get you to my lady's chamber, and tell her, let

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: her paint an inch thick, to this favour she must

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: come; make her laugh at that. Prithee, Horatio, tell

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: me one thing.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: What's that, my lord?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Dost thou think Alexander looked o' this fashion i'

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: the earth?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: E'en so.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And smelt so? pah!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Puts down the skull

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: E'en so, my lord.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To what base uses we may return, Horatio! Why may

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: till he find it stopping a bung-hole?

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: 'Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: No, faith, not a jot; but to follow him thither with

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it: as

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: thus: Alexander died, Alexander was buried,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Alexander returneth into dust; the dust is earth; of

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: earth we make loam; and why of that loam, whereto he

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: was converted, might they not stop a beer-barrel?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Imperious Caesar, dead and turn'd to clay,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Might stop a hole to keep the wind away:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: O, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Should patch a wall to expel the winter flaw!

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: But soft! but soft! aside: here comes the king.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Enter Priest,  and c. in procession; the Corpse of  OPHELIA, LAERTES and Mourners following; KING CLAUDIUS, QUEEN GERTRUDE, their trains,  and c

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The queen, the courtiers: who is this they follow?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And with such maimed rites? This doth betoken

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The corse they follow did with desperate hand

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Fordo its own life: 'twas of some estate.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Couch we awhile, and mark.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Retiring with HORATIO

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: What ceremony else?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: That is Laertes,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: A very noble youth: mark.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: What ceremony else?

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Her obsequies have been as far enlarged

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: As we have warrantise: her death was doubtful;

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: And, but that great command o'ersways the order,

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: She should in ground unsanctified have lodged

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Till the last trumpet: for charitable prayers,

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her;

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Yet here she is allow'd her virgin crants,

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Her maiden strewments and the bringing home

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: Of bell and burial.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Must there no more be done?

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: No more be done:

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: We should profane the service of the dead

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: To sing a requiem and such rest to her

speaker: First Priest
text_entry: As to peace-parted souls.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Lay her i' the earth:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: And from her fair and unpolluted flesh

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: A ministering angel shall my sister be,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: When thou liest howling.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What, the fair Ophelia!

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Sweets to the sweet: farewell!

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Scattering flowers

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet's wife;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: I thought thy bride-bed to have deck'd, sweet maid,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And not have strew'd thy grave.

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: O, treble woe

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Fall ten times treble on that cursed head,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Deprived thee of! Hold off the earth awhile,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Till I have caught her once more in mine arms:

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Leaps into the grave

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Till of this flat a mountain you have made,

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: To o'ertop old Pelion, or the skyish head

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Of blue Olympus.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: [Advancing]     What is he whose grief

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Bears such an emphasis? whose phrase of sorrow

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hamlet the Dane.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Leaps into the grave

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: The devil take thy soul!

speaker: LAERTES
text_entry: Grappling with him

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Thou pray'st not well.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I prithee, take thy fingers from my throat;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: For, though I am not splenitive and rash,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Yet have I something in me dangerous,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Which let thy wiseness fear: hold off thy hand.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Pluck them asunder.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Hamlet, Hamlet!

speaker: All
text_entry: Gentlemen,--

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: Good my lord, be quiet.

speaker: HORATIO
text_entry: The Attendants part them, and they come out of the grave

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Why I will fight with him upon this theme

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Until my eyelids will no longer wag.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: O my son, what theme?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I loved Ophelia: forty thousand brothers

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Could not, with all their quantity of love,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Make up my sum. What wilt thou do for her?

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: O, he is mad, Laertes.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: For love of God, forbear him.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: 'Swounds, show me what thou'lt do:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Woo't weep? woo't fight? woo't fast? woo't tear thyself?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Woo't drink up eisel? eat a crocodile?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I'll do't. Dost thou come here to whine?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: To outface me with leaping in her grave?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Be buried quick with her, and so will I:

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: And, if thou prate of mountains, let them throw

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Millions of acres on us, till our ground,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Singeing his pate against the burning zone,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Make Ossa like a wart! Nay, an thou'lt mouth,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I'll rant as well as thou.

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: This is mere madness:

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: And thus awhile the fit will work on him;

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: Anon, as patient as the female dove,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: When that her golden couplets are disclosed,

speaker: QUEEN GERTRUDE
text_entry: His silence will sit drooping.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Hear you, sir;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: What is the reason that you use me thus?

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: I loved you ever: but it is no matter;

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Let Hercules himself do what he may,

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: The cat will mew and dog will have his day.

speaker: HAMLET
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: I pray you, good Horatio, wait upon him.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exit HORATIO

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: To LAERTES

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Strengthen your patience in our last night's speech;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: We'll put the matter to the present push.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Good Gertrude, set some watch over your son.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: This grave shall have a living monument:

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: An hour of quiet shortly shall we see;

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Till then, in patience our proceeding be.

speaker: KING CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
